An indication of whether a person is classified as disabled under the American's with Disability Act (ADA).

A person having intellectual disability; hearing impairment, including deafness; speech or language impairment; visual impairment, including blindness; serious emotional disturbance (hereafter referred to as emotional disturbance); orthopedic impairment; autism; traumatic brain injury; developmental delay; other health impairment; specific learning disability; deaf-blindness; or multiple disabilities and who, by reason thereof, receive special education and related services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) according to an Individualized Education Program (IEP), Individual Family Service Plan (IFSP), or service plan.

A prescribed span of time when an education institution is open, instruction is provided, and students are under the direction and guidance of teachers and/or education institution administration. A session may be interrupted by one or more vacations.
A local code given to the session, usually for a session that represents a term within the school year such as a marking term.
A short description of the Session.
Indicates that the session is a marking term.
Indicates that the session is a scheduling term.
Enables sessions to be linked (e.g. link a marking term to a scheduling term)
The year, month and day on which a session begins.
The year, month and day on which a session ends.

Role of the person (eg, teacher, parent, principal, student, etc).
A network-resolvable Uniform Resource Locator (URL) pointing to the authoritative reference for the competency framework item
A human-referenceable code designated by the publisher to identify the item in the hierarchy of competency framework items.
The title or name of the assessment.
The topic category evaluated by this assessment

A measure of average performance in all courses taken by a person during his or her school career as determined for record-keeping purposes. This is obtained by dividing the total grade points received by the total number of credits attempted. This usually includes grade points received and credits attempted in his or her current school as well as those transferred from schools in which the person was previously enrolled.

A measure of average performance in all courses taken by a person during a given session. This is obtained by dividing the total grade points received by the number of credits attempted for the same session.
The academic rank of a student in relation to his or her high school graduating class (e.g., 1, 2, 3) based on high school GPA.
A List of other addresses for the person.
The types of previous, alternate or other address for a person. Generally another residence or mailing address.
List of specific life achievements desired by student
The year, month and day on which the status of the service plan for a child is established or significantly altered.
The year, month and day on which the status of the service plan for a child effectively ends.
Evaluation Date
Label that assigns meaning to the categories that were measured (eg, x-axis label)
Label that assigns meaning to a chart display of a measured value (eg, y-axis label)
The specific accommodation necessary for assessment or instruction.
Description of a specific accommodation or change to standards or practices that will be made.
A statement of why— (A) The child cannot participate in the regular assessment; and (B) The particular alternate assessment selected is appropriate for the child.
Current accommodation Category
Description of specific accommodation or change made to environment
The description of the place where an assessment is administered.

Observations about the student’s performance in a practical learning setting
A SIF RefId.
The full legal first name given to a person at birth, baptism, or through legal change.
The full legal last name borne in common by members of a family.

Type of related or ancillary services provided to a person or a group of persons within the formal educational system or offered by an outside agency which provides non-instructional services to support the general welfare of students. This includes physical and emotional health, the ability to select an appropriate course of study, admission to appropriate educational programs, and the ability to adjust to and remain in school through the completion of programs. In serving a student with an identified disability, related services include developmental, corrective, or supportive services required to ensure that the person benefits from special education.
Indicates that services are provided to the child in a place where children of all abilities learn together.
The date on which the goal becomes active.
The date on which the goal expires or has been achieved.
The reason given for declining the recommended services.
Determination if this service continues outside school year.
A list of applicable education levels.
The education level, grade level or primary instructional level at which a course is intended.
Grade level at beginning of the IEP effective period
Explanation for choice of other or information refining grade level selection.
Restrictions for student and/or teacher contact with the individual (e.g., the student may not be picked up by the individual.
Indicates whether or not the learner lives with the related person.

Indicates that a person is a primary contact within the specified context, such as a primary parental contact specified in Person Relationship to Learner or a primary administrative contact for an organization.
Indicates whether or not the person is a designated emergency contact for the learner.
The numeric order in the preferred sequence and priority for contacting a person related to the learner.

The unique identifier for the locally defined rotation cycle date code when the class meets (e.g., in a two day schedule, valid values could be "A" and "B", or "1" and "2").
The day(s) of the week (e.g., Monday, Wednesday) that the class meets or an indication that a class meets "out-of-school" or "self-paced".
An indication of the portion of a typical daily session in which students receive instruction in a specified subject (e.g., morning, sixth period, block period, or AB schedules).
A unique number or alphanumeric code assigned to a room by a school, school system, state, or other agency or entity.
An indication of the time of day the class begins.
An indication of the time of day the class ends.

This is the reference identifier of the student, for when the student record is expected to be retrievable. This is an alternative to the student though both may be present.

A coding scheme that is used for identification and record-keeping purposes by schools, social services, or other agencies to refer to a student.
A unique number or alphanumeric code assigned to a student by a school, school system, a state, or other agency or entity.
The setting in which children ages 6 through 21, receive special education and related services.
The program in which children ages 3 through 5 attend and in which these children receive special education and related services.

The rationale for the placement decision and if applicable, an explanation of the extent, if any, to which the child will not participate with nondisabled children in the regular class and in the activities described in paragraph (a)(4) of CFR. §300.320.

A measure of average performance in all courses taken by a person during his or her school career as determined for record-keeping purposes. This is obtained by dividing the total grade points received by the total number of credits attempted. This usually includes grade points received and credits attempted in his or her current school as well as those transferred from schools in which the person was previously enrolled.

A measure of average performance in all courses taken by a person during a given session. This is obtained by dividing the total grade points received by the number of credits attempted for the same session.
The academic rank of a student in relation to his or her high school graduating class (e.g., 1, 2, 3) based on high school GPA.
